document.masterDocTitle: The Italian species of the Chthonius ischnocheles group (Arachnida, Pseudoscorpiones, Chthoniidae), with reference to neighbouring countries

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The Italian species of the Chthonius ischnocheles group (Arachnida, Pseudoscorpiones, Chthoniidae), with reference to neighbouring countries

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Chelifer ischnochelus Hermann, 1804: 118
, pl. 5 fig. p, pl. 6 fig. 14.

Obisium megachelum Amary, 1840: 78
, tab. IV, figs 1b–d, 3a–b ( n. syn. ).

Chthonius rayi dalmatinus Hadži, 1930: 72
, figs 10a–e, 11a–e, 12a–b, 13a–d, 14, 15a–b, 16a–c ( n. syn. ).

Chthonius (C.) litoralis Hadži, 1933: 130
, figs 2a–c ( n. syn. ).

Chthonius (C.) rhodochelatus Hadži, 1933: 133
, figs 3c, 4a–b, 5a–c, 6b–e, 7 ( res. syn. ).

Chthonius (C.) ischnocheles ischnocheles : Callaini 1979a: 131
(in part: see
C. densedentatus
).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality
: not stated, presumably near Strasbourg ( France ) ( Harvey 2013 )
.
Distribution . Species widespread throughout Europe, Macaronesia and Anatolia , introduced to the U.S.A. and St. Helena ( Harvey 2013 ).

Diagnosis ( ♂ ♀ ).
An eyed epigean
Chthonius
that differs from other species of the
ischnocheles
group in the following combination of characters: anterior margin of carapace with 2 (rarely 1) preocular microsetae; posterior margin of carapace with 4 macrosetae, lateral setae as long as or slightly shorter than the median setae; chelicerae with 3 (rarely 2 or 4) lateral microsetae; spinneret wide and semicircular; chela length 0.885–1.70 mm ; movable finger length 0.56–1.08 mm ; chelal fingers with reclined, pointed and widely spaced teeth; fixed chelal finger with 31–49 teeth; ratio of pedipalpal femur/carapace 1.25–1.6.

Type material of
Chthonius rayi
examined.
ITALY —
Alto Adige : Bolzano Prov.
— 1 ♀ , ( lectotype of
Chthonius Rayi L. Koch, 1873
, present designation), “Hauenstein” [Castelvecchio near Siusi allo Sciliar, com. Castelrotto,
1273 m a.s.l.
, 46°32’10”N , 11°34’06”E ] “
Chthonius Rayi L. Koch
” “13.9.1.810–959” “
Chthonius rayi L. Koch
/ syntypes / M. Judson det. 1993” ( NHM ); 82 ♂ 57 ♀ ( paralectotypes of
Chthonius Rayi
, present designation), same data as lectotype (together with 6 ♂ 27 ♀ of
C. carinthiacus
) ( NHM )
.

(granulation omitted).

FIGURES 245–252.
Chthonius ischnocheles ( Hermann, 1804 )
, Castiglione delle Stiviere (Mantova). 245, male, right chela, antiaxial view (hand granulation omitted); 246, male, detail of fingers at the chelal tip, antiaxial view; 247, male, detail of fingers at level of trichobothria est-it and st-t , antiaxial view; 248, male, detail of fingers at level of trichobothrium sb , antiaxial view; 249, female, right chela, antiaxial view (hand granulation omitted); 250, female, detail of fingers at the chelal tip, antiaxial view; 251, female, detail of fingers at level of trichobothria est-it and st-t , antiaxial view; 252, female, detail of fingers at level of trichobothrium sb , antiaxial view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description of adults ( ♂ ♀ ).
Integument strongly pigmented, carapace and tergites reddish- or greenish-brown, chelicerae and pedipalps reddish-brown; marked scale-shaped granulation on lateral surfaces of carapace, on cheliceral palm, on base of pedipalpal femur, on base of fixed and movable chelal fingers and on surface of chelal hand; glandular pores scattered across the entire surface of carapace, cheliceral palm and palpal hand. Carapace ( Figs 239 , 254 ) 0.85–0.95 times longer than broad, trapezoidal, constricted posteriorly; anterior margin denticulate between median macrosetae, with a prominent epistome ( Figs 237–238 , 253 ); ocular area as in figs 239–240, 254, anterior eyes with convex lens (diameter 0.04–0.06 mm ), posterior eyes with flat lens, distance from anterior eyes to anterior margin of carapace
0.035 –0.055 mm
, distance from anterior to posterior eyes 0.06–0.10 mm ; all eyes with a tapetum; standard chaetotaxy mm 4mm :6:4:2:4(24), but widely variable even within populations: anterior row rarely mm 4m or m 4m , posterior row rarely with 5 macrosetae [ ♂ from Rocchetta Vara (La Spezia), Campomarino (Termoli) and Erbalunga ( Corsica ); ♀ from Villetta Di Negro (Genoa)] or mm3 ( ♀ from Villa Ada, Rome) or m4 ( ♀ from Parco Caffarella, Rome), lateral setae of posterior row long as or slightly shorter than the median setae; length of anteromedian macrosetae 0.10–0.16 mm , all setae thick. Chaetotaxy of tergites 4:4:4:4:6:6:6:6:1T2T1:4:1T2T1: 0. Chaetotaxy of sternites II–X: 9–12:(3)8–11(3):(2)7–9(2):8–11:6–8:6:6:6:2T1T2, sternite II mainly with 10 setae, st. IV–V mainly with 8 setae; genital opening of males flanked by 5–10 (mainly 7–8) setae on each side. Chelicerae ( Figs 241 , 255 ) 2.0–2.2 times as long as broad, palm with 6 (rarely 7) setae and 3 [rarely 2 ( ♂ ♀ from Saarland; ♂ from Limski canal, Istria) or 4 ( ♀ from Erbalonga, Corsica ; ♂ from Castiglione delle Stiviere, Mantova)] lateral microsetae, surface of the palm with scattered, non-glandular pores; fixed finger with 2 distal large teeth followed by 6–9 small teeth and 4–5 proximal microtubercles; movable finger with an isolated subapical tooth ( di ) at level with the spinneret, followed by a large tooth and 6–9 teeth proximally reduced in size; gs ratio 0.56–0.65; spinneret wide and semicircular, mainly similar in both sexes ( Figs 241–242 , 255–256 ); rallum with 11 blades; serrulae interior and exterior with 15–17 and 17–18 blades respectively. Coxal setae: pedipalp 5 (including 2 on manducatory process), I 3 + 3 marginal microsetae, II 4, III 5, IV 6; coxa II with 6–21 coxal spines, coxa III with 3–12 coxal spines (coxae II with 6 and 7 coxal spines in ♂ from Cave Badde o Su Guanu, Pozzomaggiore, with 20 and 21 coxal spines in ♀ from Zannone Isl., Latium; coxae III with 3 and 3 coxal spines in ♀ from Villa Ada, Rome, with 9 and 12 coxal spines in ♂ from Castiglione delle Stiviere, Mantua); intercoxal tubercle bisetose.(with 1m in ♂ from Villa Ada, Rome). Pedipalp: femur 4.65–5.65 ( ♂ ) or 4.6–5.2 ( ♀ ) times as long as broad, femoral chaetotaxy 3:6:2:5–6:1; chela ( Figs 245, 249 , 258 ) 5.2–6.3 ( ♂ ) or 4.65–5.45 ( ♀ ) times as long as deep; hand of chela 1.9–2.1 ( ♂ ) or 1.75–2.05 ( ♀ ) times as long as deep, with parallel sides or with long ovoid outline in dorsal view ( Figs 243–244 , 257 ); fixed chelal finger with 31–43 ( ♂ ) or 33–49 ( ♀ ) broad, widely spaced teeth, cuspidate and inclined backwards, increasingly reduced towards finger base; the 5–8 distal teeth small and contiguous, the 3–6 proximal ones short and apically rounded ( Figs 246–248, 250-252 , 259-265 ), all teeth with dental canal; fixed finger at level of est-it with 3–4 ( ♂ ♀ ) teeth occupying 0.1 mm , distance between successive apices 0.020 –0.034 ( ♂ ) or 0.023 –0.036 ( ♀ ) mm; tip of fixed chelal finger with apical sensilla af
1- 2
, distal paraxial seta gradually curved and thin; movable chelal finger with 33–47 ( ♂ ♀ ) teeth, reclined and apically pointed in the distal half of the finger, rounded in the proximal half of the finger and increasingly reduced from sb towards finger base ( Figs 246–248, 250-252 , 259-265 ); movable finger at level of st-t with 4–5 ( ♂ ♀ ) teeth occupying 0.1 mm , distance between successive apices 0.018 –0.023 ( ♂ ) or 0.018 –0.027 ( ♀ ) mm; coupled sensilla pc just distad of sb , rarely at level at sb ; tip of movable chelal finger with apical sensilla am
1- 2
; trichobothria as in figs 245, 249, 258; ratio sb -st/sb -b = 1.8–2.0; ratio of movable finger/hand of chela 1.6–1.9 ( ♂ ) or 1.6–1.8 ( ♀ ); ratio of pedipalpal femur/movable finger 1.0–1.2 ( ♂ ) or 1.0–1.1 ( ♀ ); ratio of pedipalpal femur/ carapace 1.3–1.6 ( ♂ ) or 1.25–1.5 ( ♀ ).

Description of tritonymph. Integument pigmented, hispid granulation less marked than in adults. Carapace 0.85–0.95 times longer than broad, form of anterior margin and eyes as in adults; diameter of anterior eyes 0.035 mm ; chaetotaxy m 4m :6:4:2:4(22), anterior row rarely mm 4m ; length of anteromedian macrosetae 0.09–0.10 mm , all setae thick. Chaetotaxy of tergites as in adults. Chaetotaxy of sternites II–IX 5:(2)8(2):(1)7–8(1):8–9:6:6:6:6. Chelicerae 2.0–2.05 times as long as broad, palm with 5 setae and 2 lateral microsetae; fixed finger with 7–10 teeth, proximally reduced in size, and a few proximal microtubercles; movable finger with an isolated subapical tooth ( di ) and 6–8 teeth; gs ratio 0.56–0.59; spinneret as in adults. Coxal setae: pedipalp 5 (including 2 on manducatory process), I 3 + 2 marginal microsetae, II 4, III 5, IV 5; coxa II with 5–11 coxal spines, coxa III with 3–5 coxal spines; intercoxal tubercle bisetose. Pedipalp: femur 4.3–4.7 times as long as broad; chela 5.1–5.2 times as long as deep; hand of chela 1.85–1.9 times as long as deep; fixed chelal finger with 33–38 widely spaced teeth, all with dental canal; movable chelal finger with 25–35 teeth, reduced in size towards finger base, reaching back near b ; coupled sensilla pc nearer b than to st ; ratio of movable finger/hand of chela 1.75–1.8; ratio of pedipalpal femur/movable finger 1.0–1.05; ratio of pedipalpal femur/carapace 1.1–1.2.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 253–265.
Chthonius ischnocheles ( Hermann, 1804 )
, Meje (Split, Croatia) (unless otherwise stated). 253, male, anterior margin of carapace; 254, male, carapace; 255, male, right chelicera; 256, female, movable finger of right chelicera; 257, male, right chelal hand, dorsal view; 258, male, right chela, antiaxial view; 259, male, detail of fingers at the chelal tip, antiaxial view; 260, male, detail of fingers at level of trichobothria est-it and st-t , antiaxial view; 261, male, detail of fingers at level of trichobothrium sb , antiaxial view; 262, male paralectotype of
Chthonius rayi
(“Hauenstein”), detail of fingers at the chelal tip, antiaxial view; 263, id., detail of fingers at level of trichobothria est-it and st-t , antiaxial view; 264, id., detail of fingers at level of trichobothrium sb , antiaxial view; 265, male (Guldenbachtal bei Seibersbach, Germany), right chela, detail of fingers at level of trichobothria est-it and st-t , antiaxial view.

subSubSection.paragraph: Measurements (in mm). Body length 1.5–1.8. Carapace 0.40–0.47 × 0.41–0.53 (0.38–0.50 anteriorly). Chelicerae 0.34–0.46 × 0.18–0.225, movable finger length 0.19–0.235. Pedipalp: femur 0.44–0.58 × 0.10–0.135; chela 0.67– 0.86 × 0.13–0.165; hand length 0.24–0.31; movable finger length 0.43–0.55.

Remarks. Thanks to information kindly provided by Dr M. Judson (MHNP), I recently learned of a publication by Amary (1840) that was unknown to me when I compiled the Italian pseudoscorpions catalogue ( Gardini 2000 ). It contained the first described Italian pseudoscorpion,
Obisium megachelum Amary, 1840
, from Capri Isl., that was compared by the author to
Chthonius ischnocheles .
The nice figure of the whole specimen ( Amary 1840 , tab. IV, fig. 1b) allows, in addition to the obvious attribution to the genus
Chthonius
, a clear view of a prominent epistome. The type specimen is not traceable in the collections of the “ Centro Musei delle Scienze Naturali e Fisiche” (University of Naples Federico II) (R. Improta, in litt.: October 11, 2018 ) and it is presumed lost. Currently, four species of the genus
Chthonius
with an epistome are known from Campania :
C. ischnocheles , C. stammeri , C. jonicus
and
C. ilvensis
.
Chthonius stammeri
is an hypogean species and endemic to the Alburni Mts., both
C. jonicus
and
C. ilvensis
are small species that are slightly pigmented, but
C. ischnocheles
matches the illustration by Amary (1840) and it is the only known
Chthonius species
from Capri (see above under Material examined).
Obisium macrochelum Amary, 1840
is therefore a junior subjective synonym of
Chthonius ischnocheles ( Hermann, 1804 )
( n. syn. ).

Chthonius rayi L. Koch, 1873
—described from several localities in France , Italy and Great Britain —was synonymized with
C. ischnocheles
by Chamberlin (1929) . The examination of syntypes of
C. rayi
from Hauenstein (Castelrotto, Bolzano) (NHM 13.9.1.810–959) revealed the presence of a mixture of five species:
C. ischnocheles
( 82 ♂ 57 ♀ ),
C. carinthiacus
( 6 ♂ 27 ♀ ),
Ephippiochthonius tetrachelatus (Preyssler, 1790)
( 1 ♀ ),
Neobisium carcinoides ( Hermann, 1804 )
( 1 ♀ ) and
Roncus alpinus L. Koch, 1873
(right chela of a specimen). The above designation of a lectotype for
C. rayi
is therefore appropriate.

With regards to the other newly proposed synonyms, it is necessary to carefully summarize the taxonomic history of the species complex
C. dalmatinus - litoralis - rhodochelatus
.

One female and two males of
Chthonius
were found ( May 24, 1925 ) in a garden at Sali (Dugi Otok Isl., Croatia ). One male was referred by Hadži (1930) to
Chthonius rayi L. Koch, 1873
but the other male and the female were described as
C. rayi dalmatinus
ssp. nova . The most important character to justify the description of the new subspecies was the number of setae on the posterior margin of carapace: 4 in
C. rayi
and 6 in
C. rayi dalmatinus
but note that in Hadži’s drawings (1930: 73, figs 10a–b), the female of
C. rayi dalmatinus
is depicted with 6 basal setae, while the male has 4 setae. Other differences mentioned by Hadži (1930) to distinguish the two taxa (different length between movable and fixed chelal fingers, dentition of chelicerae, number and arrangement of cheliceral setae) are of little taxonomic value from today’s perspective.

The three specimens attributed by Hadži (1930) to
Chthonius rayi
(=
C. ischnocheles
) and to
C. rayi dalmatinus
were subsequently attributed to the
C. orthodactylus - tenuis
group, although not belonging to any of its already known species ( Hadži 1933 ).
Chthonius dalmatinus
was separated from
C. rayi
and diagnosed against
C. ischnocheles
by having two preocular microsetae on each side (only one on each side in
C. ischnocheles
), and the posterior margin of carapace with 2 median macrosetae and 2 lateral microsetae on each side (4 subequal macrosetae in
C. ischnocheles
).
Chthonius dalmatinus
was also compared with
C. italicus
, which has the same chaetotaxy on the posterior margin of carapace.

The male attributed by Hadži (1930) to
Chthonius rayi
was therefore described ( Hadži 1933 ) as
C. litoralis
n. sp. in the
C. orthodactylus – tenuis
group and differentiated from
C. dalmatinus
by having one preocular microseta on each side (2 microsetae in
C. dalmatinus
), the posterior margin of carapace with 4 subequal macrosetae (2 macrosetae and 2 lateral microsetae on each side in
C. dalmatinus
), and the cheliceral palm with 2 lateral microsetae ( 3 in
C. dalmatinus
). It should be emphasized therefore that
C. litoralis
, compared by Hadži (1933) only with
C. dalmatinus
, would have the same carapacal chaetotaxy of
C. ischnocheles .

Hadži (1933) described
Chthonius rhodochelatus
n. sp. from Omisalj (Krk Isl.), Meje near Split ( type locality) and Novi Vinodolski in Croatria, and compared these specimens with
C. litoralis
.
Chthonius rhodochelatus
has 2 preocular microsetae on each side, the posterior margin of carapace with 4 macrosetae (the lateral shorter than the median ones) and the cheliceral palm with 3 lateral microsetae. Hadži (1933) highlighted the size differences among his specimens, especially noting that the specimens from Omisalj were smaller than the types from Split, and probably belonged to a geographical race ( geografsku rasu ) of
C. rhodochelatus .
Differences in the reciprocal distance among teeth of fixed chelal finger between specimens from Split and those from Omisalj are mentioned in the text, stating that teeth of the fixed finger are only apparently spaced ( katkad samo prividno ) in specimens from Omisalj. The figures do not provide any possibility of comparison, since the left chela of male from Omisalj is only represented in dorsal view ( Hadži 1933: 137 , fig. 6a). Drawings of the right chela of a specimen from Split ( Fig. 6b ), and above all the detail of the fixed chelal finger ( Fig. 6c ), show clearly spaced teeth at the level of the trichobothria est-it.

Beier (1963b) proposed, without justification, the synonymy between
Chthonius rhodochelatus
and
C. ischnocheles .
More recently Gardini (2004) , following the examination of specimens collected at Omisalj, proposed to remove
C. rhodochelatus
from the synonymy with
C. ischnocheles
and attributed to
C. rhodochelatus
specimens from France , Slovenia , Croatia , Corfù and Italy . Specimens from Omisalj, and the other specimens examined, share the presence of almost contiguous teeth (widely spaced teeth in
C. ischnocheles
) and the carapacal chaetotaxy of mm 4mm :6:4:2:m 2m (mm 4mm :6:4:2: 4 in
C. ischnocheles
).

The type specimens of
Chthonius dalmatinus , C. litoralis
and
C. rhodochelatus
cannot be located at the Institute of Zoology at the University of Ljubljana , the Slovenian Academy of Sciences and Arts, or the Prirodoslovni muzej Slovenije in Ljubljana (T. Novak & T. Trilar, in litt.: December 4, 2012 ). It is possible that they are in the collections of the Institute of Zoology of Univ. of Belgrade but a request for information ( December 14, 2018 ) from that institution went unanswered.

Thanks to the kindness of R. Ozimec ( Zagreb ), I have had the opportunity to examine a male and a female ( Figs 253–261 ) of
Chthonius
collected by him in Meje near Split, the type locality of
C. rhodochelatus
. They correspond well with the description provided here for
C. ischnocheles
, but also with Hadži’s description (1933) of
C. rhodochelatus
. This allows me to propose, following Beier (1963b) ,
Chthonius rhodochelatus Hadži, 1933
as a newly restored synonym of
C. ischnocheles ( Hermann, 1804 )
( res. syn. ). Specimens from Omisalj ( Hadži, 1933 ) are attributed here to
C. densedentatus
(see Material examined and Remarks under this species).

The above description of
Chthonius ischnocheles
highlights the high variability of carapacal chaetotaxy even within populations, both in number of preocular microsetae, and in number and length of setae on posterior margin of carapace, in addition to the number of lateral microsetae on the cheliceral palm. The main characters proposed by Hadži (1930 , 1933 ) in describing
C. dalmatinus
and
C. litoralis
are fully included in those of
C. ischnocheles .
This allows me to propose the following synonymies:
Chthonius dalmatinus Hadži, 1930
and
Chthonius litoralis Hadži, 1933
are junior subjective synonyms of
Chthonius ischnocheles ( Hermann, 1804 )
( n. syn. ).

Chthonius rhodochelatus reductus
was described by Beier (1939) from females collected in a cave on Giuppana Isl. (Šipan Isl., Dubrovnik, Croatia ) and subsequently ( Beier 1963b ) recorded also from Corfu and considered as
C. ischnocheles reductus .
Following Beier (1963b) , it differs from
C. ischnocheles ischnocheles
primarily in the reduction of the eyes, the carapacal chaetotaxy and in the dentition of the chelal fingers: fixed chelal finger with 48 teeth ( 40 in
C. ischnocheles
), movable chelal finger with 25 teeth ( 36 in
C. ischnocheles
) that are proximally reduced to a thickly serrated lamella (see also Beier 1939: 9 , fig. 2).
Chthonius reductus Beier, 1939
( n. stat. ) is upgraded here from
C. ischnocheles reductus Beier, 1939
and given species rank.

The description and measurements of
Chthonius ischnocheles
provided by Gabbutt & Vachon (1963) , Mahnert (1985) ,
Zaragoza et al. (2007)
and Zaragoza & Vadell (2013) agree with the above description of
C. ischnocheles ,
except for some minor discrepancies: cheliceral palm with 1 or 2 lateral microsetae in adult and 1 microseta in tritonymph for Gabbutt & Vachon (1963) , 3 (rarely 2) and 2 microsetae, respectively, in the present study; female chela 5.9 times as long as broad at most for Mahnert (1985) , 5.45 times as long as deep at most in the present study.

Among the Italian species of the
Chthonius ischnocheles
group,
C. ischnocheles
is morphologically most similar to the epigean
C. densedentatus
that often occurs in sympatry, and to the hypogean
C. stammeri
from Campania . It differs from
C. densedentatus
in the following main characters: posterior margin of carapace with 4 setae, lateral setae long as or slightly shorter than the median ones (with 2 setae and 2 lateral microsetae, at most one third of medial macrosetae long, in
C. densedentatus
); fixed chelal finger at level of est-it with 3–4 ( ♂ ♀ ) teeth occupying 0.1 mm , distance between successive apices 0.020 –0.034 ( ♂ ) or 0.023 –0.036 ( ♀ ) mm [with 5–7 ( ♂ ♀ ) teeth occupying 0.1 mm , distance between successive apices 0.013 –0.018 ( ♂ ) or 0.013 –0.023 ( ♀ ) mm in
C. densedentatus
]; movable chelal finger at level of st-t with 4–5 ( ♂ ♀ ) teeth occupying 0.1 mm , distance between successive apices 0.018 –0.023 ( ♂ ) or 0.018 –0.027 ( ♀ ) mm [with 5–8 ( ♂ ♀ ) teeth occupying 0.1 mm , distance between successive apices 0.012 –0.020 ( ♂ ) or 0.012 –0.022 ( ♀ ) mm in
C. densedentatus
]. For comparison of
C. ischnocheles
with
C. stammeri ,
see Remarks under the latter species.

The male of
Chthonius ischnocheles
recorded from the cave Buca delle Fate, Tuscany ( Callaini 1986b: 523 , figs 1c–d) is a misidentification of
C. densedentatus ,
and the specimen identified as
C. ischnocheles reductus
quoted from Corfu ( Beier 1963b ), briefly described and depicted by Inzaghi (1987: 180 , figs 18–20), most likely refers to
C. densedentatus
. Many records of
C. ischnocheles
from Veneto ( Lazzeroni 1969b: 390 ) are misidentified
C. densedentatus
(see Material examined under
C. densedentatus
).

Italian records of
Chthonius ischnocheles
reported by Gardini (2000) remain to be verified, due to likely misidentifications with
C. densedentatus .
